What is this?

The GeneticMilling project uses genetic algorithms to optimise a shoulder milling operation by choosing the best cut width and cut height to minimise maching time without destroying the tool.

We Start the simulation with a population of 50 individuals, each representing a cutting operation with a randomly generated cut width and cut depth. A tournament selection method is used to determine the best cutting parameters for each generation. This involves running several "tournaments" among a few individuals from the population, usually those with the highest fitness. The winners are selected for crossover where its parameters are passed onto the next generation. Once this process is repeated for a number of generations the average fitness for the population will be increased, and the fitness individual from the population is used for the simulation.
